div.p: From Stanley Dobson to James Service
A84/8354, unit 59, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

You asked me through your Secretary a question or two about the proposed Botanical Key.
See, in the same file, S. Dobson to E. Thomas, 17 September 1884. I received today a letter from my old friend General Sir H Lefroy R.A. lately Governor of Tasmania a letter, I had sent him a copy of the annual address of the Field Naturalists Club which I as the President had to deliver in April last. Sir Henry says — and he is no mean authority in the Scientific world: "I hope you will succeed in persuading your Government to issue a Botanical Guide on the plan of Spicer's
Spicer (1878). but a little fuller. One often feels that a word or two more would save much uncertainty at crucial points. The size of the flower the prevailing colour and so on".

If more money were to be asked for I can understand your putting your foot down but where the Baron says his present vote already passed will suffice — will you not take the advice of a man like myself who has no possible axe to gring but who feeling that the Barons hitherto published works are but of small practical utility to Botanical studies — point out the advantages which must result from a work of an entirely different character. I have had many a prowl up Mount Wellington with Sir H. Lefroy and aided by our Spicers Key we have never failed to ascertain the position in the Botanical world which the specimen were discussing occupied.

The Baron tells me it will not cost more than £170. Surely then you will allow him to expend this absurdly small sum in a book which cannot fail to impart a scientific stimulus.
See also S. Dobson to J. Service, 20 September 1884 (in this edition as M84-09-20).
